Hi @yue-fred-gao , I have find another issue caused by this PR. Since the default route is removed, we are not able to ssh to the DPU from the switch, because there is no route to the NPU mgmt IP:

admin@sonic:~$ sudo tcpdump -i eth0-midplane tcp dst port 22 -vvv
[ 4334.346618] device eth0-midplane entered promiscuous mode
tcpdump: listening on eth0-midplane, link-type EN10MB (Ethernet), snapshot length 262144 bytes
06:06:03.992403 IP (tos 0x0, ttl 62, id 22881, offset 0, flags [DF], proto TCP (6), length 60)
 **10.210.24.178**.37242 > 169.254.200.1.ssh: Flags [S], cksum 0x8334 (correct), seq 1884908377, win 64240, options 

admin@r-SN4280-10:~$ show ip interface | grep eth0
eth0 **10.210.24.178**/22 up/up N/A N/A

May I ask where do you configure the route to the NPU mgmt IP?

From the switch, you should have a subnet route 169.254.200.0/24 over eth0-midplane. So when you ssh to a DPU, eth0-midplane should be picked as the outgoing interface and its ip address (165.254.200.254) should be used as source IP, not the NPU mgmt IP. I think you can check in your setup why NPU mgmt IP is used instead.

> can we please ensure the test case itself is asic agnostic?

Hi Rita

The test itself is pretty much agnostic of the ASIC, we have tested on TH based platforms and are in the process of enabling it for DNX etc. In case it needs to be enabled for other vendors there may be minor changes needed in the yaml file to add pg_min_threshold etc.

> do we have same coverage for multi-asic device too?

Hi Rita

The test already uses the `get_src_dst_asic_and_duts` fixture, which is the standard mechanism for multi-ASIC support in QoS SAI tests. Looking at the code:


```
def testQosSaiPgMinThreshold(
 self, ptfhost, dutTestParams, dutConfig, dutQosConfig,
 get_src_dst_asic_and_duts # ← Already has multi-ASIC fixture!
):
 # ...
 src_dut_index = get_src_dst_asic_and_duts['src_dut_index']
 src_asic_index = get_src_dst_asic_and_duts['src_asic_index']
 dst_dut_index = get_src_dst_asic_and_duts['dst_dut_index']
 dst_asic_index = get_src_dst_asic_and_duts['dst_asic_index']
 
 src_testPortIps = dutConfig["testPortIps"][src_dut_index][src_asic_index]
 dst_testPortIps = dutConfig["testPortIps"][dst_dut_index][dst_asic_index]
 
```

For multi-asic duts the indices are automatically set as the following

```
 dst_dut_index = src_dut_index
 src_asic_index = 0
 dst_asic_index = 1
 
```

We don't have mulit-asic duts available in house but if they are available the test will automatically

- Detect multi-ASIC DUTs via duthost.sonichost.is_multi_asic
- Select appropriate ASICs based on topology

Only thing needed would be the following

```
@pytest.mark.parametrize("test_port_selection_criteria", 
 ["single_asic", "single_dut_multi_asic"])
def testQosSaiPgMinThreshold(
...
)
```

@ansrajpu-git 

Thanks for pointing out testQosSaiPGDrop! I've reviewed both tests and they serve different purposes: testQosSaiPGDrop (currently disabled) characterizes the **exact packet count** that triggers ingress drops on a **single PG** through multiple iterations with precise threshold validation (abs(actual - expected) < margin), requiring highly tuned parameters for each platform, whereas testQosSaiPgMinThreshold validates **comparative behavior between two PGs** (one with MIN threshold, one without) in a single test run to ensure that lossy PGs drop more packets than lossless PGs with reserved buffers, working with approximate buffer values and providing more maintainable functional validation. These tests complement rather than overlap: testQosSaiPGDrop is for platform characterization (if re-enabled), while testQosSaiPgMinThreshold validates the specific functional behavior of PG MIN reserved buffers, which is not covered by the existing test. I believe testQosSaiPgMinThreshold adds value as a separate test for this reason.

I believe keeping them separate provides better test clarity, easier maintenance (testQosSaiPgMinThreshold works with approximate values vs precise tuning), and clearer failure diagnosis.
